snippet: FEGS Health and Human Services, the city’s biggest provider of job placement services, announced a shortfall of nearly $20 million, then said it would close its programs.
abstract: Rachel L Swarns The Working Life column examines surprising downfall of FEGS Health and Human Services, one of New York City's most august social service agencies; observes that organization folded after discovery of $19.4 million budget shortfall, leaving city officials scrambling to provide job placement, mental health care, housing and other services to tens of thousands of vulnerable residents.
lead_paragraph: FEGS Health and Human Services, the city’s biggest provider of job placement services, announced a shortfall of nearly $20 million, then said it would close its programs.

headline.print_headline: With Little Warning, Agency Aiding the City’s Most Vulnerable Crumbles
headline.main: With Little Warning, Agency Aiding New York’s Most Vulnerable Crumbles
